channel.title: The Register
channel.description: Biting the hand that feeds IT

item.title: Last.fm to extend scrobbler tech to video
item.description:
Building a musical empire, despite DRM

Last.fm, the popular music website, is to apply its social recommendation technology to video, as it prepares to do battle with Pandora for the internet radio station market.…

item.title: Dutch reject USB flash drive tax
item.description:
Heated debate

Dutch justice minister Hirsch Ballin has rejected calls for a copyright tax on USB flash drives.…

item.title: Y2K7 bug causes isolated glitches
item.description:
Windows and Google AdWords among the temporally confused

Clockwatch We may have been little premature yesterday in declaring that America survived Sunday's Daylight Saving Time (DST) switch unscathed.…

item.title: Cisco Borgs NeoPath
item.description:
Storage management purchase

Cisco is buying NeoPath, a small Silicon Vallley storage management software vendor. Terms for the privately-held company are undisclosed.…

item.title: Once again, 'Vladuz' impales eBay defenses
item.description:
Getting ridiculous

For at least the third time in as many months, a malicious hacker has gained unauthorized access to parts of eBay's network despite the best efforts of the company's security team to fortify its system against the embarrassing breaches.…

item.title: Intel on sale for $20
item.description:
Bit by bits

Fanboys everywhere can now buy Intel by the bit.…

item.title: Breathe blows off Biscit deal
item.description:
No other suitors yet

Breathe’s rescue of Biscit Internet is off, the would-be rescuer announced this afternoon.…

item.title: 'World's first' transistor-printing plant opens
item.description: Austrian manufacturer Nanoident Technologies today cut the ribbon on the world's first factory that literally prints opto-electronic sensor circuitry and components.…

item.title: VSTO For Mere Mortals
item.description:
Assuming that Office Power Users think of themselves as mortals...

Book review In addition to the legions of professional Visual Basic programmers, there are still more developers who use VBA and Microsoft Office for automation, customisation or the development of tailored office applications. Many of these are super-users rather full-time developers, but they have depended on VBA to extend and expand what it is they can do with Excel, Office, Access et al.…

item.title: Demonic car takes out TelecityRedbus
item.description:
As it dodges WGA

Letters What? Keep the lights on? Forget global warming, it's all about budget allocation?…

item.title: The Holy Grail of services: SCA
item.description:
Service Component Architecture as a way to build SOA

How many times lately have you come across a column on Service Oriented Architecture (or SOA)? Or an article telling you that SOA is the next big thing? Or that SOA is the way we should all be building systems?…

item.title: NEC warms up unlaunched storage grid
item.description:
No need for disaster recovery

NEC has announced the imminent arrival of its grid storage system which it claims will remove the need for planned downtime, amongst other things.…

item.title: Storage market spins out of control
item.description:
Well, it grew a bit, says IDC

Research house IDC reckons the worldwide storage market reached $4.8bn last year - a six per cent growth on last year.…

item.title: Viacom sues Google for $1bn
item.description:
The party's over

Viacom's patience with Google has finally run out, and the entertainment giant has filed a $1bn copyright infringement suit against Google.…

item.title: Computacenter product business stages comeback
item.description:
Flip-flop

Computacenter has managed to tighten its belt a couple of notches and turn its infrastructure business into its headline feature - for the right reasons.…

item.title: ECS to fly Flybook wannabe into CeBIT
item.description:
Firm's G200 looks strangely familiar...

Taiwanese hardware maker Elitegroup ECS yesterday revealed it's going to be demo'ing at Germany's CeBIT show this week. One offering caught our eye: the G200 laptop, which sports an "ingenious... smart neck that allows the screen to be lifted, tilted or swiveled to a comfortable level for the user".…

item.title: Al Gore brings TV for Guardianistas to UK
item.description:
What do you know, you can marry your cousin

Yesterday saw the UK launch of yet another TV-on-the-internet company - only this one is also TV-on-the-internet-on-TV.…

item.title: If you must pirate, use counterfeit Windows
item.description:
MS exec gets pragmatic about piracy

A senior Microsoft exec has admitted that some software piracy actually ends up benefiting the technology giant because it leads to purchases of other software packages.…

item.title: Sony set to shrink PSP
item.description:
No change to screen size, though

Remember claims made in August 2006 that Sony is planning to redesign the PlayStation Portable? It turns out they were true. Sony Computer Entertainment UK chief Ray Maguire yesterday confirmed a "smaller, lighter" version is on its way.…

item.title: Disney launches interactive site for mums
item.description:
While Eisner invests in web content studio

Disney is launching a new website, Disney Family, aimed specifically at mums. The media giant says the site will host user generated articles, and will eventually form a "Parent Pedia", with information on hundreds of subjects of interest to mums and dads.…

item.title: Guards to stake out Milosevic grave
item.description:
Dracula-style come-back still possible

Vampire hunters wishing to prevent Slobodan Milosevic rising from his grave will now have to deal with security guards posted to prevent them driving a stake through his heart and thereby thwarting any ambitions the Serbian dicatator may have for a Dracula-style political comeback.…

item.title: ORG to enlighten music industry on DRM's limitations
item.description:
Readying a white paper

The Open Rights Group (ORG) is developing a new paper to inform the music industry about the technical suitability of Digital Rights Management (DRM) as an aid to enforcing copyright.…

item.title: Radio phone-ins might be dodgy too
item.description:
And David Gest shouldn't have left the jungle

Another day, another flurry of stories about dodgy phone-ins.…

item.title: BSA fires off writs against online resellers
item.description:
Watchdog cries foul over 'dodgy' software auctions

The Business Software Alliance (BSA) has begun an international clampdown against people selling illegitimate software online.…

item.title: IBM chief puzzles over payslip
item.description:
Does that say $18.8m or is it $24.46m?

Puzzling over your pension statements and worried about chomping your way through this year’s tax return?…

item.title: Ten reasons why you should buy a PlayStation 3
item.description:
£450 well spent?

Tech Digest Is that the wind of changed opinions blowing? Since last week's Games Developers Conference (GDC) in San Francisco, the buzz about Sony's PlayStation 3 has taken a turn for the better.…

item.title: Non-glamorous gambling ads to hit UK from September
item.description:
Sally Army up in Arms

Ads for online and traditional gambling will hit the UK's airwaves from September, the government has confirmed.…

item.title: Apple slip exposes eight-core Mac Pro
item.description:
Quad-core Xeon machine imminent?

Apple may be about to equip its Mac Pro desktop with Intel four-core Xeon processors, if an inadvertent posting on the company's UK online store is to be believed.…

item.title: IBM produces smaller Cells
item.description:
Destined for servers not PS3, at least not at the start...

IBM has beguin punching out a 65nm version of the Cell processor used in Sony's PlayStation 3. Gamers should not get too excited: Big Blue's Broadband Engine - to give Cell its full name - is aimed not at consoles but slimline servers.…

item.title: Oracle buys another database
item.description:
Trying to snatch IBM's crown?

Comment Oracle and IBM are both competitors and partners. In the case of databases they are certainly rivals, with Oracle 10g and DB2 going head-to-head at many sites. However, it has occurred to me to wonder if Oracle is seeking to rival IBM's crown as the owner of the most different databases.…

item.title: UK's biometric passports go jumbo
item.description:
Super size me

The Identity and Passport Service (IPS) has produced a larger version of the biometric passport.…

item.title: Buddhist video game aims to teach morals
item.description:
Outbreak of kindness expected in Thailand

We hear a lot about violence in video games being to blame for all the ills besetting the youth of today. Now, a Thai games developer has decided it is time to right the balance and has developed a snappily titled Ethics Game to teach youngsters about being good, decent and teetotal.…

item.title: Atari can appeal because law may change before hearing
item.description:
Case pending two landmark verdicts

A claim in a court case over payment discrepancies to the author of Atari computer games can proceed because the law may have changed by the time the case gets heard.…

item.title: Even wee companies must adhere to WEEE regulations
item.description:
Size doesn't matter

Even small companies must provide free, environmentally-sound disposal of the electronic equipment they sell, according to new government guidelines (PDF) intended to clarify the WEEE Regulations.…

item.title: What's Green for Wal-Mart is Green for America
item.description:
Scorecards for consumer electronics makers

The Greening of Wal-Mart, America's least popular popular retailer, continues apace. This time it is putting the squeeze on consumer electronics suppliers, with a scorecard to assess the "sustainability of their products".…

item.title: MacBook goes up in flames
item.description:
Suitable for BBQ marshmallow roasting

In the latest episode of The Laptop Infernos, a MacBook user is reporting his laptop came close to burning his house down after the battery exploded and burst into flames. The MacBook, which was less than a year-old, was charging with the lid shut when it spontaneously ignited at about three in the morning while the user and his girlfriend slumbered.…

item.title: Gross, glorious Las Vegas – a model for web designers
item.description:
The good, the bad and the chubby

SXSW Those web designers obsessed with their mashed up, CSS, AJAX injections may want to book a trip to Las Vegas and learn some lessons from fat people chowing down in the all-you-can-eat buffet.…

item.title: Etilize catalogs antitrust suit against CNET
item.description:
Patent suit over reseller data feeds

CNET today turned from newsgather to newsmaker when it got a lawsuit accusing it of anti-competitive behavior.…

item.title: Blog Nation embraces Rather after flaying him
item.description:
First we destroy, then we love

SXSW Grizzled Texan newsman Dan Rather received the warmest of welcomes from the grand blog felch that helped end his CBS career, during a speech today here at the SXSW conference and festival. The blogger nation found Rather's call for better US journalism inspirational, particularly when he chastised the candy ass reporters covering the White House.…

item.title: Three more charged for pump-and-dump hacking
item.description:
Fed cracking down on securities manipulation

US authorities have charged three Indian nationals for an elaborate pump-and-dump scheme that used hijacked brokerage accounts to manipulate the prices of 14 securities including Sun Microsystems and put options for Google.…

item.title: Y2K7 bug fails to bite
item.description:
Aclockalypse Not

Panic over: America survived Sunday's onslaught of Daylight Saving Time (DST) on Sunday unscathed. For a while, Bug-watchers thought that GoDaddy, the domain registrar, might have mismanaged the time-change, after customers reported outages. But a good old-fashioned DDOS attack was the culprit.…

item.title: Fraud, not incompetence, to blame for Nortel's accounting fiasco
item.description:
SEC charges four execs

The SEC today threw the book at four former Nortel execs for cooking the books. Frank Dunn, ex-CFO and CEO at the Canadian telecoms equipment maker, Douglas Beatty, ex-controller and CFO, Michael Gollogy, ex-controller, and MaryAnne Pahaphil, ex-assistant controller, are accused of manipulating secret cash reserves and recognizing revenues earlier than they should have done to meet Wall Street expectations and to line their own pockets.…

item.title: Intel 'Robson' Flash cache reborn as USB unit
item.description:
Not just for laptops now, too

Updated Intel has become the latest chip maker to offer a Flash-based solid-state hard drive, though it's pitching the part not as a replacement for magnetic hard disk storage but as an adjunct to it.…

item.title: IBM and Cisco send Global alliance worldwide
item.description:
The World Series of networking services

IBM and Cisco are expanding their Global Services Alliance, er globally.…

item.title: UK airline pilot sacked for sightseeing tour
item.description:
Ignored 'Pull Up' warning in Shetland jaunt

The pilot of a passenger plane who flew fives miles off course in bad weather to "show his co-pilot the scenery" has been sacked, the Daily Telegraph reports.…

item.title: Lights go out at colo centre
item.description:
TelecityRedbus suffers power failure

TelecityRedbus's colocation centre on Marsh Wall in London's Docklands has apparently suffered a power failure and back-up generators have not kicked in.…

item.title: Dodgy food science: eating press releases is bad for you
item.description:
Chocolate pilchards, anyone?

Chocolate is not just (possibly) good for your brain, it can ward off strokes, dementia, heart disease and cancer.…

item.title: Blogebrities campaign for fair treatment
item.description:
Want to have their cake and blog about it

SXSW Professional bloggers have demanded to be taken still more seriously by mainstream media and have current measures of their blog-induced fame reassessed.…

item.title: Call goes out for open source teledildonics work
item.description:
Free Software Poundation

SXSW NSFW The computational dildo liberation army (CDLA) has called out device makers for creating boring old kit that just doesn't get the job done. The dildo patrol want to see more creative devices and an influx of open source effort around sex toys.…

item.title: McAfee maps malware risk domains
item.description:
Neighbourhood watch

A global road map of the riskiest and safest places to surf online found Russian and Romanian sites among the top-level domains most commonly hosting malicious downloads, browser exploits, and scams.…
